questions.text: Which of the following is not seen in low insulin-glucagon ratio?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Glycogen storage

 

A low insulin: glucagon ratio (IGR) stimulates mobilization of stored nutrients, increases glycogenolysis and gluconeogenesis, ketogenesis and promotes the breakdown of adipose tissue into free fatty acids and glycerol.

 

Conversely, glycogen storage is not promoted during a low insulin-glucagon ratio. Glycogen storage occurs in a high insulin state, where insulin promotes the uptake and storage of glucose as glycogen in liver and muscle tissues.

 

Other Options :

 

The processes influenced by a low IGR include:

 

Option A. Glycogen Breakdown (Glycogenolysis): The breakdown of glycogen into glucose is stimulated to provide immediate energy.

 

Option B. Ketogenesis: The production of ketone bodies from fatty acids occurs in the liver as an alternative energy source, particularly for the brain during prolonged fasting.

 

Option D. Gluconeogenesis: The synthesis of glucose from non-carbohydrate precursors such as lactate, glycerol, and amino acids is enhanced to maintain blood glucose levels.

 

Educational Objective :

 

A low insulin-glucagon ratio stimulates the mobilization of energy stores by promoting glycogen breakdown, ketogenesis, and gluconeogenesis, while it inhibits glycogen storage.

choices.text: Abortion leading to death of mother
Preventing the child from being born alive

questions.text: IPC Section 314 deals with? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Abortion leading to death of mother

 

ABORTION IPC’S = 312-316 IPC’S, 317 & 318

 

312 – 316 → Criminal Abortion

 

312 – Criminal abortion with consent of mother (BNS section 88)

 

313 – Criminal abortion without the consent of mother (BNS section 89)

 

314 – Death of mother during criminal abortion (BNS section 90)

 

315 - Preventing a live birth or causing a live born to die after birth (BNS section 91)

 

316 – Causing death of quick born, by a heinous act which could have led to death of mother (ex: - hit on abdomen of mother) (BNS section 92)

 

317 - Abandoning of a child by parents when child age is <12 years (BNS section 93)

 

318 - Concealing the birth of a newborn by secret disposal of dead body (BNS section 94)

 

Educational Objective:

 

IPC Section 314 deals specifically with the death of the mother during a criminal abortion.

questions.text: Calcium deposition is seen in which layer? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) D

 

Calcium deposition occurs primarily in the zone of calcified cartilage, which is represented by option D in the image. This zone is located near the metaphysis of a growing bone, where cartilage is being replaced by bone tissue. The calcification process involves the accumulation of calcium salts in the cartilage matrix, leading to its hardening and subsequent replacement by bone. This is a crucial step in the endochondral ossification process, which allows for the longitudinal growth of bones.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A: This layer represents the reserve zone, where chondrocytes are relatively inactive and not yet undergoing proliferation or hypertrophy. Calcium deposition does not occur in this zone.

 

Option B: This layer is the proliferative zone, where chondrocytes are rapidly dividing. While important for bone growth, this zone does not involve calcium deposition.

 

Option C: This is the hypertrophic zone, where chondrocytes increase in size and prepare for calcification. Although it is a precursor to the calcification process, actual calcium deposition occurs in the next zone.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The zone of calcified cartilage is where calcium deposition occurs, leading to the hardening of cartilage and its eventual replacement by bone during the growth of long bones.

questions.text: Reflex responsible for tachycardia during right atrial distension?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Bainbridge reflex

 

Bainbridge reflex is a cardioaccelerator reflex that increases the heart rate when venous return is increased. Since this reflex arises from right atrium, it is also called right atrial reflex.

 

 

Other Options :

 

Option A. Bezold-Jarisch Reflex: Bezold-Jarisch reflex is the reflex characterized by bradycardia and hypotension, caused by stimulation of chemoreceptors present in the wall of left ventricles by substances such as alkaloids. It is also called coronary chemoreflex. Vagal fibers form the afferent and efferent pathways of this reflex.

 

Option C. Cushing Reflex: Cushing reflex is a protective reflex that helps save the brain tissues from ischemic effects during the periods of reduced cerebral blood flow. It is also called Cushing reaction, response or phenomenon.

 

Option D. J Reflex: Apnea followed by rapid breathing, bradycardia, and hypotension due to J receptor (C-receptor, juxta-pulmonary capillary receptor) stimulation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Bainbridge reflex is a cardiovascular reflex that increases heart rate in response to increased venous return, enhancing cardiac output to match the increased blood flow into the heart.

questions.text: Which among the following according to the latest guidelines is NOT an indication to IE prophylaxis? (Neet pg 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Atrial Septal Defect

 

According to the latest guidelines, there are specific indications for infective endocarditis (IE) prophylaxis to prevent infection in high-risk patients. These indications include:

 

  1. Prior Infective Endocarditis: Patients with a history of infective endocarditis are at increased risk for recurrence and hence, are recommended for prophylaxis.
  2. Prosthetic Valves: Patients with prosthetic heart valves, especially mechanical valves, are susceptible to infections and require prophylaxis.
  3. Cardiac Transplant with Valvulopathy: Those who have undergone cardiac transplant and have developed valvulopathy are also indicated for IE prophylaxis.
  4. Congenital Heart Disease: This includes any unrepaired cyanotic congenital heart disease, repaired congenital heart disease with prosthetic material for the first six months post-repair, or repaired congenital heart disease with residual defects.

 

Atrial Septal Defect (ASD) is not listed among these high-risk conditions. ASD, especially without significant gradient across the atria or significant shunting, has a very low risk of causing infective endocarditis. Therefore, ASD does not fit into the current guidelines for IE prophylaxis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Prior Infective Endocarditis: Prior infective endocarditis significantly increases the risk of recurrent infection, thus requiring IE prophylaxis as per the guidelines.

 

Option C. Unrepaired Cyanotic Congenital Heart Disease: Unrepaired cyanotic congenital heart disease is a high-risk condition for infective endocarditis, necessitating prophylaxis.

 

Option D. Cardiac Transplant with Valvulopathy: Patients who have undergone a cardiac transplant and have valvulopathy are at increased risk for infection and are indicated for IE prophylaxis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Atrial Septal Defect (ASD) is not an indication for infective endocarditis prophylaxis according to the latest guidelines, whereas prior infective endocarditis, prosthetic valves, cardiac transplant with valvulopathy, and certain congenital heart diseases are key indications.

questions.text: Xanthurenic Acid in urine indicates: (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Vitamin B6 deficiency

 

Xanthurenic assay a.k.a. Tryptophan load test. Xanthurenic acid in urine indicates Vitamin B6 deficiency. Xanthurenic acid is a metabolite that is formed during the breakdown of the amino acid tryptophan. Under normal conditions, tryptophan is metabolized along the kynurenine pathway, which involves the conversion of tryptophan to various intermediate compounds. One of these intermediates is xanthurenic acid.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Vitamin B1 deficiency: Measurement of erythrocyte transketolase activity, thiamine pyrophosphate (TPP) effect, and blood thiamine levels.

 

Option C. Niacin deficiency: Measurement of urinary N-methylnicotinamide (NMN) excretion, and niacin load test.

 

Option D. Vitamin B2 deficiency: Measurement of erythrocyte glutathione reductase activity.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In individuals with a deficiency of vitamin B6 (pyridoxine), the conversion of tryptophan to niacin (vitamin B3) is impaired. As a result, tryptophan is metabolized through an alternative pathway, leading to the accumulation of xanthurenic acid. Therefore, the presence of xanthurenic acid in urine is indicative of a vitamin B6 deficiency.

questions.text: A 3-year-old boy is brought to the pediatric ophthalmology clinic by his parents due to concerns about a whitish glow in his right eye noticed during photographs taken with a flash. The child also has been squinting and has recently developed decreased visual interest in his surroundings. On examination, there is a white pupillary reflex (leukocoria) in the right eye, and further evaluation confirms the presence of an intraocular mass. Imaging reveals a tumor originating from the retina. The pediatric oncologist explains that early diagnosis and treatment are crucial to prevent the tumor from spreading beyond the eye. What is the most common route of the spread of this malignancy?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Direct invasion

 

Retinoblastoma is a primary intraocular malignancy that arises from the retina and most commonly spreads by direct invasion. This mode of spread involves the tumor extending into adjacent ocular structures, which can progress to involve the optic nerve and orbit if not promptly managed.

 

 

Pathophysiology:

 

Retinoblastoma is the most common primary intraocular cancer in children and arises from the neurosensory retina. It is composed of small basophilic cells with large hyperchromatic nuclei and scanty cytoplasm.

 

Clinical Presentation:

 

Common presenting signs include leukocoria (a white pupillary reflex), strabismus, decreased visual acuity, and in advanced cases, proptosis or orbital cellulitis.

 

Types of Retinoblastoma:

 

Endophytic: Tumor growth into the vitreous cavity with seeding.

 

Exophytic: Growth into the subretinal space, often causing retinal detachment.

 

Mixed Type: Combination of endophytic and exophytic patterns.

 

Progression of Disease:

 

Without treatment, retinoblastoma can progress through stages including local invasion (direct spread), extraocular extension, and distant metastasis.

 

Common Route of Spread:

 

Direct invasion is the most common route of spread in retinoblastoma, emphasizing the need for early recognition and intervention to prevent progression.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hematogenous spread: This can occur in late stages but is not the primary mode of spread.

 

Option B. Lymphatic spread: The eye does not have a lymphatic system, making this route highly unlikely.

 

Option D. Perineural spread: While it can occur, particularly involving the optic nerve, it is not as common as direct invasion.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Direct invasion is the most common route of spread in retinoblastoma, highlighting the importance of early detection and intervention to prevent the tumor from extending beyond the eye and leading to more severe outcomes.

questions.text:
Which of the following organelles is absent in the area of the cardiac muscle marked:  
(AIIMS May 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Lysosome

 

Lysosomes are not typically concentrated in the marked perinuclear area of cardiac muscle cells. Instead, lysosomes are distributed throughout the cytoplasm of the cell. This means that they are present in the cell but do not show a significant concentration or structure in the indicated area of cardiac muscle fibers.

 

In cardiac muscle cells, mitochondria are abundant due to the high-energy demand for contraction, and endoplasmic reticulum (sarcoplasmic reticulum) and Golgi bodies are usually present in the perinuclear area for synthesis and modification of proteins and other important molecules.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Mitochondria: Mitochondria are highly abundant in cardiac muscle cells, particularly near areas that need significant energy. The heart has a high demand for ATP due to its continuous contractions, and mitochondria are essential for this energy supply.

 

Option C. Golgi bodies: Golgi bodies are present in cardiac muscle cells, often localized around the perinuclear area. They are important for modifying, packaging, and sorting proteins, which are needed in various cellular functions, including those in muscle contraction and maintenance.

 

Option D. Endoplasmic reticulum (ER): The endoplasmic reticulum (or sarcoplasmic reticulum in muscle cells) is crucial for calcium storage and release, which is essential for muscle contraction. It is indeed present in cardiac muscle cells and has a significant role in the regulation of contraction and relaxation cycles.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Lysosomes are widely distributed throughout the cytoplasm of cells,

 

  1. Lysosomes are membrane-bound organelles 
  2. The enzymes within lysosomes are responsible for breaking down various cellular waste materials, such as proteins, lipids, carbohydrates, and even organelles.
  3. Lysosomes play a crucial role in cellular homeostasis by recycling and eliminating unwanted or damaged cellular components through a process known as autophagy.
  4. The acidic environment within lysosomes (pH around 4.5-5) is necessary for the optimal activity of the digestive enzymes.

 

Lysosomal storage disorders, such as Tay-Sachs disease and Gaucher's disease, occur when there is a malfunction or deficiency of enzymes within lysosomes, leading to the accumulation of undigested materials and subsequent cellular dysfunction.

questions.text: Heavy metal chelators are all EXCEPT:(INICET NOV 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Oxime

 

Oximes are not typically used as heavy metal chelators. Oximes are compounds containing the functional group R1C=NOH. They are more commonly associated with the reactivation of acetylcholinesterase in the treatment of organophosphate poisoning.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Penicillamine: Penicillamine is a heavy metal chelator used in the treatment of Wilson's disease and lead poisoning.

 

Option C. BAL (British Anti-Lewisite or Dimercaprol): BAL is a heavy metal chelator used for arsenic, gold, and mercury poisoning.

 

Option D. Trientine: Trientine is a heavy metal chelator used in the treatment of Wilson's disease.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Heavy metal chelators play a crucial role in the treatment of heavy metal poisoning. They work by binding to toxic heavy metals and aiding in their elimination from the body. Each heavy metal chelator may have specific indications and is used for particular heavy metal poisonings.

questions.text: The serum electrolyte values of a patient weighing 60 kg are given below. Calculate the sodium deficit in the patient. pH: 7.42, Na+: 120 mEq/L, serum K+: 4 mEq/L, serum CI-: 90 mEq/L? (AIIMS MAY 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 720 mEq

 

Sodium Deficit = Body weight x (0.6) x (desired sodium- actual sodium) [Note: 0.5 if female]= 60*0.6*(140-120) = 720 mEq.

 

Note: Correction should not exceed 6-8 mEq/day in chronic hyponatremia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Sodium deficit -

 

Rate of Correction: It's critical to correct chronic hyponatremia slowly to avoid complications like osmotic demyelination syndrome. The recommended rate of correction should not exceed 6-8 mEq/L per day.


Monitoring: Frequent monitoring of serum sodium levels is necessary during the correction phase to adjust the treatment as needed and prevent overcorrection.

 

Ref: Harrison 21/Fluid and electrolyte/Chap 53

choices.text: Reducing fluid intake to <500 ml per day

questions.text: The best approach in the treatment of chronic SIADH is? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Tolvaptan

 

The best approach in the treatment of chronic SIADH (syndrome of inappropriate antidiuretic hormone secretion) is to use tolvaptan.

 

Tolvaptan is a selective vasopressin V2 receptor antagonist that works by blocking the action of antidiuretic hormone (ADH) in the kidneys, leading to increased urine output and improved serum sodium levels. It is currently the preferred treatment for chronic SIADH, as it has been shown to be effective in improving symptoms and reducing the risk of complications.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Reducing fluid intake to <500 ml per day is not a recommended approach to treating chronic SIADH, as it can lead to dehydration and other complications.

 

Option C. Demeclocycline, a tetracycline antibiotic, is another treatment option for SIADH, but it is less effective and has more side effects compared to tolvaptan.

 

Option D. Fludrocortisone, a mineralocorticoid hormone, is not recommended for the treatment of SIADH, as it can worsen hyponatremia (low sodium levels) and increase the risk of fluid retention.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Tolvaptan is the best approach in the treatment of chronic SIADH due to its selective antagonism of the vasopressin V2 receptor, leading to increased urine output and improved serum sodium levels. Other methods, such as severe fluid restriction and demeclocycline, are less effective or have more side effects. Fludrocortisone is not suitable for treating SIADH and can exacerbate the condition.

questions.text: A 58-year-old male patient is undergoing central venous catheter insertion via the subclavian vein below the left clavicle, as marked in the given X-ray image. Shortly after the procedure, the patient experiences complications related to the catheter placement. What is the most common complication of central line insertion below the marked bone?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Arterial puncture

 

The most common complication of central venous catheter insertion via the subclavian vein is arterial puncture. This complication occurs because the subclavian artery lies directly beneath the vein, making it susceptible to accidental puncture during catheter placement. If the needle is advanced too deeply or at an incorrect angle, it can puncture the artery, leading to complications such as hematoma, hemothorax, and potentially severe consequences if not promptly recognized.

 

Complications of Central Venous Catheterization:

 

Arterial puncture: Most common complication; can cause bleeding, hematoma, or unrecognized arterial placement of the catheter.

 

Cardiac tamponade: A life-threatening but less common complication involving puncture of heart chambers or major vessels.

 

Pneumothorax: More frequent with subclavian access than jugular access because the chances of injury of pleural are higher in subclavian access.

 

Nerve injury: Involvement of nearby nerves like the brachial plexus or phrenic nerve, though less common.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Cardiac tamponade: Though severe, it is not the most common compared to arterial puncture.

 

Option C. Pneumothorax: A known risk in subclavian vein catheterization but less frequent than arterial puncture.

 

Option D. Nerve injury: Possible but occurs less often than arterial puncture.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Arterial puncture is the most frequent complication of subclavian vein catheterization due to the close anatomical relationship between the subclavian vein and artery. Recognizing and managing this complication promptly is essential to prevent severe outcomes during central line placement.

questions.text: During your rural internship, you are tasked with overseeing vaccine distribution to Community Health Centres (CHCs) and Primary Health Centres (PHCs). Due to the tropical climate and frequent power outages at your posting area, ensuring the vaccines' integrity is crucial. Which of the following tests would you employ to check if the vaccines have incurred any freeze damage due to temperature fluctuations? [AIIMS NOV 2018]
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Shake test

 

  • Utility: Used to check if Freeze sensitive vaccines have been damaged by exposure to freezing temperatures below 0 degrees C; After the test the previously Frozen vaccine shows flakes. Shake Test is used to assess the freeze damage to Aluminium based freeze sensitive vaccines such as DPT, TT, Td etc. 
  • Method of Shake test:
    • Test Vial: Vial which is suspected to have been frozen 
    • Frozen control vial: Take a similar (as Test vial) vaccine vial with same manufacturer, batch number, antigen(s), Label it properly. Freeze it overnight at -20 degrees C, then let it haw (Do not heat)
    • Hold the Test vial and Control vials between thumb and forefinger and shake them vigorously (10-15 seconds)
    • Place both vials on even flat surface for 30 minutes observation, compare the sedimentation rates (SR). If the sediments in the suspect vial settle more slowly, the suspect vaccine may be used.
  • Interpretation:
    • If SR in Test vial < Control vial: Vaccine had not been damaged
    • If SR in Test vial > Control vial: Vaccine had been damaged,

 

Do not use and Inform the supervisors

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Schick test: This is a skin test for susceptibility to diphtheria.

 

Option C. Habel test: This is used to measure the potency of rabies vaccines.

 

Option D. Tine test: This is a skin test for tuberculosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Shake Test currently applies to freeze sensitive vaccines which are:

 

  • DPT-Hep B-Hib
  • TT
  • PCV13
  • Hepatitis B
  • HPV

choices.text: Hospitalize for anti-venom administration and immobilization

questions.text: Which of these steps is included in the management of snake bite?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Hospitalize for anti-venom administration and immobilization

 

Management of snake bite:

 

 

Immobilization is done to minimize the spread of the venom. Hospitalization, followed by AS administration is the definitive management of snake bites.

 

Measures that can be taken in the case of snakebite:

 

  • Apply firm pressure over the bitten area, which delays the absorption of venom
  • Pressure immobilization is recommended for elapid and sea-snake bites, but not for viper bites as it may cause local necrosis
  • Immediately apply a broad firm bandage (Sutherland wrap on the bitten area and around the limb. As much of the limb should be bandaged as possible. It should be tight enough to occlude the superficial venous and lymphatic return, but not the arterial or deep venous flow. A pressure of 50 to 70 mm Hg is maintained.
  • In bites on the trunk, head, or neck, apply firm pressure over the bitten area
  • Immobilize the limb, as movement can accelerate the spread of venom
  • Make the patient lie on one side in the recovery position so that the airway is clear, in case of vomiting or fainting.

 

Measures contraindicated in the case of snakebite:

 

  • Suction and incision of the wound
  • Electric shock treatment of wound site
  • Application of tourniquets because they obstruct arterial flow and cause ischemia
  • Ice water immersion of the bitten limb
  • Do not attempt to kill or catch the snake as it may be dangerous.
  • Administration of AS locally at the wound site.
  • Herbal/local remedies

 

Other Options :

 

Option A. Loose Tourniquet: Not recommended as it can cause ischemia and increase the risk of complications.

 

Option B. Debridement: Not advisable as it can exacerbate the spread of venom.

 

Option C. Killing the Snake: Attempting to kill or catch the snake can be dangerous and is not necessary for treatment.

 

Educational Objective :

 

The management of snake bites primarily involves hospitalization for the administration of anti-venom and immobilization of the affected limb to minimize the spread of venom.

questions.text: Which of the following is NOT a typical symptom of cerebellar damage? (AIIMS NOV 2016)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Resting tremor

 

Resting tremor is typically associated with basal ganglia diseases such as Parkinsonism and not with cerebellar lesions. Cerebellar lesions produce intention tremors, which occur during voluntary movements, not at rest.

 

Other Options :

 

Option A. Nystagmus: Cerebellar lesions can cause nystagmus, which is characterized by involuntary eye movements.

 

Option B. Past pointing: This is a clinical feature of cerebellar lesions where there is increased irregularity of movements as the finger approaches a target.

 

Option D. Ataxic gait: Cerebellar lesions can lead to ataxic gait, which is characterized by a broad-based, unsteady walking pattern.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Cerebellar lesions produce intention tremors rather than resting tremors, which are seen in basal ganglia diseases like Parkinsonism

questions.text: A middle-aged man with chronic renal failure on dialysis presents with sudden collapse to the casualty with labored breathing. ECG shows tall tented T waves. What is the most likely acid-base imbalance that can be seen in this patient? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. pH- 7.14, pCO2- 20 mm Hg, HCO3-5 mEq/L

 

The patient with chronic renal failure presenting with sudden collapse and labored breathing is indicative of a severe acid-base disturbance, most likely metabolic acidosis. The tall tented T waves on the ECG suggest hyperkalemia, a common finding in metabolic acidosis and renal failure.

 

Patients with chronic renal failure often have a high anion gap metabolic acidosis due to the accumulation of uremic toxins. The lab values in pH - 7.14, pCO2 - 20 mm Hg, HCO3 - 5 mEq/L indicate a severe metabolic acidosis with respiratory compensation. The low bicarbonate level confirms metabolic acidosis, and the low pCO2 indicates compensatory hyperventilation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. pH- 7.14, pCO2- 20 mm Hg, HCO3- 34 mEq/L: This combination is inconsistent with metabolic acidosis because the bicarbonate level is high, which would not be seen in metabolic acidosis.

 

Option C. pH - 7.54, HCO3 - 27 mEq/L, pCO2-34 mm Hg: This represents metabolic alkalosis or compensated respiratory acidosis, neither of which are consistent with the clinical picture of chronic renal failure and hyperkalemia.

 

Option D. pH- 7.4, HCO3 - 27 mEq/L, pCO2- 40 mm Hg: This reflects a normal pH, which would not be seen in the acute setting described, especially with the presence of severe symptoms and hyperkalemia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Patients with chronic renal failure are at risk for high anion gap metabolic acidosis. In cases of sudden collapse with labored breathing and ECG changes like tall tented T waves, metabolic acidosis with compensatory respiratory alkalosis is the most likely diagnosis.

Correct sequence of events during inflammation:

  2. Cytokine mediated integrin activation
  3. Adhesion
  4. Migration

 

CELLULAR CHANGES DURING INFLAMMATION

 

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The correct sequence of intravascular cellular events during inflammation involves rolling, cytokine-mediated integrin activation, adhesion, and migration.

 

Ref: Robbins and Cotran pathologic basis of disease 10th edition pg. 78-79

choices.text: Dystrophic with increased serum calcium
Metastatic with increased serum calcium
Dystrophic with normal serum calcium

questions.text: A 58-year-old man died 24 hours after the onset of substernal chest pain radiating to the left arm. On autopsy, an atheromatous plaque was seen obstructing the left anterior descending artery. Which type of calcification is most likely to be seen in this condition? (AIIMS MAY 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Dystrophic with normal serum calcium

 

Atheromatous plaques show dystrophic calcification in the presence of normal calcium levels in the serum.

 

The deposition of calcium in dead or dying tissues is called dystrophic calcification. Although it occurs in the presence of normal serum calcium, it can be worsened by hypercalcemia.

 

Dystrophic calcification is seen in areas of necrosis of any type -

 

Calcification in dead tissue –

 

  1. Caseous necrosis in tuberculosis is the most common site for dystrophic calcification.
  2. Liquefaction necrosis in chronic abscesses may get calcified.
  3. Fat necrosis following acute pancreatitis or traumatic fat necrosis in the breast results in deposition of calcium soaps.
  4. Gamma-Gandy bodies in chronic venous congestion (CVC. of the spleen is characterized by calcific deposits admixed with hemosiderin on fibrous tissue.
  5. Infarcts may sometimes undergo dystrophic calcification.
  6. Thrombi, especially in the veins, may produce phleboliths.
  7. Hematomas in the vicinity of bones may undergo dystrophic calcification.
  8. Dead parasites like in hydatid cyst, Schistosoma eggs, and cysticercosis are some of the examples showing dystrophic calcification.
  9. Calcification in breast cancer detected by mammography.
  10. Congenital toxoplasmosis involving the central nervous system visualized by calcification in the infant brain.

 

Calcification in degenerated tissues

 

  1. Dense old scars may undergo hyaline degeneration and subsequent calcification.
  2. Atheromatous in the aorta and coronaries frequently undergo calcification.
  3. Mönckeberg’s sclerosis shows calcification in the tunica media of muscular arteries in elderly people
  4. Stroma of tumors such as uterine fibroids, breast cancer, thyroid adenoma, goitre etc. show calcification.
  5. Some tumors show characteristic spherules of calcification called psammoma bodies or calcospherites such as in meningioma, papillary serous cystadenocarcinoma of the ovary and papillary carcinoma of the thyroid.
  6. Cysts which have been present for a long time may show calcification of their walls e.g. epidermal and pilar cysts.
  7. Calcinosis cutis is a condition of unknown cause in which there are irregular nodular deposits of calcium salts in the skin and subcutaneous tissue.
  8. Senile degenerative changes may be accompanied by dystrophic calcification such as in costal cartilages, tracheal or bronchial cartilages, and pineal gland in the brain etc.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Dystrophic with increased serum calcium: Dystrophic calcification typically occurs in the setting of normal serum calcium levels. While hypercalcemia can exacerbate dystrophic calcification, it is not a defining feature.

 

Option B. Metastatic with increased serum calcium: Metastatic calcification occurs when calcium salts are deposited in normal tissues as a result of hypercalcemia. This form of calcification is not associated with tissue injury or necrosis and typically affects tissues like the lungs, stomach, kidneys, and blood vessels under conditions of high serum calcium. It does not apply to the situation described, where calcification is occurring in damaged tissue with normal calcium levels.

 

Option D. Metastatic with normal serum calcium: This option is incorrect because metastatic calcification is always associated with hypercalcemia, not normal serum calcium levels.

 

Educational Objective:

 

 

Ref: Robbins and Cotran pathologic basis of disease, 8th edition, Pg no 83

questions.text: The sodium iodide symporter is present in all of the following except?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Pituitary gland

 

Sodium iodide symporter is present in all of the options given above except the pituitary gland. The pituitary does not play a direct role in iodide transport or thyroid hormone synthesis, hence the absence of NIS.

 

The sodium/iodide cotransporter, also known as the sodium/iodide symporter (NIS) is a transmembrane glycoprotein, which transports two sodium cations (Na+) for each iodide anion (I−) into the cell. NIS mediated uptake of iodide into follicular cells of the thyroid gland is the first step in the synthesis of thyroid hormone.

 

Other Options :

 

Option A. Thyroid gland: The primary site of NIS expression, essential for thyroid hormone production.

 

Option B. Placenta: NIS is expressed to transport iodide to the fetus, crucial for fetal development.

 

Option D. Salivary gland: NIS facilitates iodide transport, although its precise role here is less clear.

 

Educational Objective :

 

The sodium iodide symporter (NIS) is essential for iodide transport in various tissues. The NIS seen in:

 

  • Thyroid
  • Salivary glands
  • Gastric mucosa
  • Placenta
  • Ciliary body of the eye
  • Choroid plexus
  • Mammary glands
  • Certain cancers are derived from these tissues.

choices.text: Involves degranulation of mast cells
Can occur on first exposure
Most commonly caused by NSAIDs

questions.text: True about anaphylactoid reaction are all except: (AIIMS NOV 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) IgE mediated

 

  • Anaphylactoid reactions are defined as those reactions that produce the same clinical picture with anaphylaxis but are not IgE mediated, occur through a direct nonimmune-mediated release of mediators from mast cells and/or basophils or result from direct complement activation.
  • Unlike the classic anaphylaxis which occurs on re-exposure to the allergen, the anaphylactoid reaction can occur even on the first exposure. The most common agents that can cause an anaphylactoid reaction include NSAIDs and radiocontrast media.

 

According to World allergy organization (WAO) anaphylaxis guidance 2020

 

IgE-mediated anaphylaxis is considered the classic and most frequent mechanism. In this type, anaphylaxis is triggered by the interaction of an allergen (usually a protein) interacting with the allergen-specific IgE/high-affinity receptor (FcεRI) complex expressed on effector cells, predominantly mast cells and basophils. This initiates intracellular signaling resulting in the release of preformed and de novo synthesis of mediators.

 

Non–IgE-mediated anaphylaxis may be immunologic or non-immunologic

 

  • Non-IgE-mediated immunologic mechanisms may involve the activation of pathways such as the complement system (anaphylatoxins, C3a, and C5a), the contact and coagulation system activation or immunoglobulin G (IgG)- mediated anaphylaxis.
  • Non-immunologic mechanisms have been described for some drugs (opioids). Ethanol and physical factors, such as exercise, may be involved in triggering anaphylaxis through mechanisms which are not fully elucidated. Mast cells may be activated through receptors by certain drugs such as neuromuscular blocking agents and fluoroquinolones.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Involves degranulation of mast cells: This is true for both anaphylaxis and anaphylactoid reactions, where mast cells release histamine and other mediators, leading to the symptoms.

 

Option C. Can occur on first exposure: This is true for anaphylactoid reactions, as they do not require prior exposure or sensitization to the allergen.

 

Option D. Most commonly caused by NSAIDs: This is true. NSAIDs are a common cause of anaphylactoid reactions, which can occur without prior exposure.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Anaphylactoid reactions are not IgE-mediated and can occur on first exposure to the triggering substance, with NSAIDs being one of the common causes.

questions.text:
You are working as a casualty medical officer. A 16-year-old girl is brought to the casualty by her parents after alleged sexual assault, the girl refuses physical examination. Which of the following would you do?

  1. Start treatment for STD and pregnancy

  2. Inform the police

  3. Record refusal of consent

  4. Take vaginal samples

  5. Start medical examination
questions.solution:
Ans. A. 1, 2 and 3

 

As the girl is under 18 years of age, the medical practitioner must follow the guidelines of the Protection of Children from Sexual Offences (POCSO) Act 2012, which include:

 

1. Start treatment for STD and pregnancy: The medical officer should begin prophylactic treatment for sexually transmitted infections (STIs) and pregnancy to ensure the girl's health and safety.

 

2. Inform the police: It is mandatory to report the alleged sexual assault to the police, as it involves a minor.

 

3. Record refusal of consent: The refusal of the girl to undergo a physical examination must be documented properly to respect her autonomy and legal rights.

 

Other Options:

 

4. Take vaginal samples: This should not be done without the girl's consent, as it violates her autonomy and legal rights.

 

5. Start medical examination: Any physical examination must be consented to by the patient. In this case, the girl has refused consent, so the examination should not proceed.

 

Educational Objective:

 

As the girl is under 18 years of age, as per POCSO (The Protection of Children from Sexual Offences) act 2012, the medical practitioner should start treatment for STI & pregnancy, inform the police and record the refusal of consent for examination

questions.text: A 65-year-old male presents with chronic fatigue, unintentional weight loss, and generalized lymphadenopathy. His laboratory tests reveal leukocytosis, and a peripheral blood smear shows the presence of smudge cells. Physical examination confirms multiple enlarged lymph nodes. The clinical findings raise suspicion for a hematologic malignancy, and further diagnostic evaluation is necessary. Which of the following additional investigations would be most appropriate to confirm the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Immunophenotyping by flow cytometry

 

The clinical presentation of chronic fatigue, lymphadenopathy, and the finding of smudge cells on the peripheral smear are highly suggestive of chronic lymphocytic leukemia (CLL). The most appropriate next step to confirm the diagnosis is immunophenotyping by flow cytometry, which identifies specific cell surface markers that are characteristic of CLL.

CD5+, CD23+, CD20+, CD19+: These markers are typically positive in CLL, distinguishing it from other B-cell malignancies.

 

Surface Immunoglobulins: Often IgM and IgD with monoclonal light chains (λ or κ type), which indicate a clonal B-cell population.

 

The immunophenotype helps differentiate CLL from other lymphomas, such as mantle cell lymphoma (MCL) and follicular lymphoma, based on the pattern of CD5, CD10, and Cyclin D1 expression.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Bone marrow biopsy: While it provides information about marrow involvement, it is not required for the initial diagnosis of CLL.

 

Option B. Lymph node biopsy: Useful if transformation or another type of lymphoma is suspected, but not primarily needed for confirming CLL.

 

Option D. PET-CT scan: Assesses disease extent and lymph node involvement but is not essential for the initial diagnostic confirmation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Immunophenotyping by flow cytometry is essential in diagnosing chronic lymphocytic leukemia (CLL) by identifying specific cell surface markers. This approach differentiates CLL from other hematologic malignancies and guides appropriate management decisions.

questions.text: A patient presents with urethral discharge. A gram stain smear is made from the discharge sample and the following microscopic image is seen. What is the most likely causative organism? (INICET NOV 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Neisseria gonorrhea

 

The clinic history along with microscopic image is suggestive of Neisseria gonorrhea.

 

Gram-negative, intracellular, cocci, usually seen in pairs (diplococci) with the adjacent sides flattened (typically kidney-shaped); (Looks like two coffee beans kissing).

 

In urethral discharge, it is predominately found within the polymorphs.

 

Gonococci do not contain capsules (meningococci do).

 

Virulence factors -

 

  • Pili: Pili mediate attachment to mucosal cell surfaces and also are antiphagocytic. Piliated gonococci are usually virulent, whereas nonpiliated strains are avirulent.
  • Lipooligosaccharides (LOS)
  • Outer membrane proteins and Opa proteins eg. Porin A: mediates invasion of the epithelial cells.
  • IgA protease hydrolyzes secretory IgA, which could otherwise block the attachment of Neisseria gonorrheae to the mucosa.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Trichomonas: Trichomonas vaginalis is a flagellated protozoan and not a gram-negative diplococcus.

 

Option B. Chlamydia trachomatis: Causes urethritis but is an obligate intracellular bacterium that does not show the gram-negative diplococcus morphology.

 

Option D. Gardnerella: Associated with bacterial vaginosis and presents as gram-variable coccobacilli, not gram-negative diplococci.

 

Educational Objective :

 

The presence of gram-negative, intracellular, kidney-shaped diplococci in urethral discharge is characteristic of Neisseria gonorrhea, a common causative agent of sexually transmitted infections resulting in urethritis.

questions.text: Desmosomes are abundant in which of the following layer of skin?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) A

 

Desmosomes are abundant in the stratum spinosum layer of the epidermis of the skin. Stratum spinosum in the above image is represented by 'A'.

 

The desmosomes appear like spines on microscopy and hence this layer is also called as the prickle layer.

 

Keratinocytes in the skin's epidermis are connected by desmosomes, also known as macula adherens. It is a cell structure designed specifically for adhesion between cells.

 

  • Due to their strong adhesiveness, they can withstand mechanical stress.
  • Desmoglein (Dsg), Desmocollin (DsC), and DesmoPlakin (Dp) are some of the proteins found in desmosomes.
  • Acantholysis can result from the separation of keratinocytes caused by the loss of any one protein.
  • Pemphigus vulgaris is an autoimmune condition brought on by antibodies that target Desmoglein found in desmosomes.
  • Loss of desmosomes causes keratinocyte cohesion to break down (acantholysis), which leads to blister formation.
  • Diseases of the skin and the heart can result from desmosome dysfunction. The primary cause of arrhythmogenic right ventricular cardiomyopathy is mutations within the desmosomes (ARVC).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Stratum Corneum (B): This layer is the outermost layer of the epidermis, consisting of dead, keratinized cells. Its main function is to provide a barrier to protect underlying tissue.

 

Option C. Stratum Basale (D): This is the deepest layer of the epidermis, responsible for generating new cells. Desmosomes are present here but not as abundant as in the stratum spinosum.

 

Option D. Stratum Granulosum (C): This layer is characterized by granules of keratohyalin, which play a role in the keratinization process of the skin cells. While desmosomes may be found in this layer, they are more prominent in the stratum spinosum.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The stratum spinosum, indicated by arrow A, is the layer of the skin where desmosomes are most abundant. These structures are key for cell adhesion and strength in this layer, which is situated above the stratum basale and below the stratum granulosum.

 

Ref - Rooks textbook of dermatology- 9th Edition: Volume 1 Chapter 2, Page no 2.1, 2.2, 2.18

questions.text: A poor farmer with a history of successive crop failure develops progressive spastic paraparesis, signs of upper motor neuron paralysis, and gait instability. Name the toxin responsible for this condition. [NEET PG  2023]
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) Beta-oxalyl-amino-alanine

 

Given clinical scenario points to a diagnosis of neurolathyrism, for which the toxin responsible is beta-oxalyl-amino-alanine (BOAA).

 

Lathyrism is of two types:

 

  • Neurolathyrism: In human beings
  • Osteolathyrism: In animals

 

Neurolathyrism is caused by eating the pulse ‘Khesari Dal (Lathyrus sativus)’. Diets containing over 30% of this dal consumed over a period of 2 - 6 months result in neurolathyrism

 

Lathyrism affects 15 - 45 years of age

 

  • Toxin: present in lathyrus seeds is ‘Beta oxalyl amino alanine (BOAA)’Q
  • It manifests as following stages:
    • Latent stage
    • No-stick stage
    • One-stick stage
    • Two-stick stage
    • Crawler stage
  • Interventions for prevention and control of Lathyrism:
    • Vitamin C
    • Banning the crop
    • Removal of toxin: Steeping method and Parboiling
    • Education
    • Genetic approach
    • Socio-economic changes

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Aflatoxin: Toxin produced by Aspergillus species. It causes aflatoxicosis and is commonly found in contaminated ground nuts.

 

Option C. Ergot alkaloids: Toxins produced by Claviceps species, leading to ergotism. Found in contaminated cereals.

 

Option D. Fusarium toxin: Toxins produced by Fusarium species, which can contaminate grains and other food products, causing fusarium toxicity.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Food Adulteration Diseases

questions.text: Which among the following is the most specific disease caused by Streptococcus agalactiae?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Neonatal sepsis

 

Streptococcus agalactiae, also known as Group B Streptococcus (GBS), is a significant cause of neonatal infections. It is the leading cause of neonatal sepsis and meningitis globally. The bacteria exhibit beta-hemolysis on blood agar, characterized by complete lysis of red blood cells around the colonies, forming a clear zone. This hemolytic property helps in identifying and differentiating it from other types of Streptococci. GBS is biochemically identified as hippurate hydrolysis positive and CAMP test positive, both of which are unique to this bacterium. These tests confirm its identity and help in diagnosing infections caused by it.

 

Other Options :

 

Option B. Infective endocarditis: Although Streptococcus agalactiae can occasionally cause infective endocarditis, it is not the most specific or common disease caused by this bacterium. Infective endocarditis is more commonly associated with other Streptococcus species, such as Streptococcus viridans.

 

Option C. Dental caries: Dental caries are typically associated with Streptococcus mutans, not Streptococcus agalactiae. S. mutans plays a primary role in the development of tooth decay due to its ability to ferment sugars into acids, which demineralize the dental enamel.

 

Option D. Pharyngitis with or without tonsillitis: Pharyngitis, commonly known as strep throat, is primarily caused by Streptococcus pyogenes (Group A Streptococcus), not Streptococcus agalactiae. S. pyogenes is known for causing various suppurative and non-suppurative infections, including pharyngitis, rheumatic fever, and post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Streptococcus agalactiae (Group B Streptococcus) is the most common cause of neonatal sepsis and meningitis.

choices.text: No need additional dose since she is ICT negative
Give another dose of Anti-D 72 hour postpartum irrespective of baby blood group
Give another dose of Anti-D 72 hour postpartum depending on the baby blood group

questions.text: Rh negative mother, ICT negative was given Anti D during 28 weeks of pregnancy. Which of the following is the ideal one? (INICET MAY 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Give another dose of Anti-D 72 hour postpartum depending on the baby blood group

 

In Rh-negative women with an Rh-positive partner, Anti-D immunoglobulin prophylaxis is administered to prevent Rh sensitization. If the mother is ICT (Indirect Coombs Test) negative, an initial dose of Anti-D (300 mcg IM) is given at 28 weeks of gestation. Following delivery, an additional dose of Anti-D should be administered within 72 hours if the newborn is Rh-positive. This prevents the mother from forming antibodies against Rh-positive fetal red blood cells that might have entered her circulation during delivery.

 

  • Anti-D (300 mcg IM) at 28 weeks: Given if ICT is negative.
  • Postpartum dose within 72 hours: Required if the baby is Rh-positive. This dose is essential to neutralize any fetal Rh-positive red cells that might have entered the mother's bloodstream during delivery.

 

Other Options :

 

Option A. No need for an additional dose since she is ICT negative: Incorrect. Even if the ICT is negative, an additional dose is necessary postpartum if the baby is Rh-positive to prevent sensitization.

 

Option B. Give another dose of Anti-D 72 hours postpartum irrespective of baby blood group: Incorrect. The postpartum dose is only required if the baby is Rh-positive.

 

Option D. All of the above: Incorrect as not all options are correct.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Prophylaxis in Rh-negative women with an Rh-positive partner involves giving Anti-D (300 mcg IM) at 28 weeks (if ICT is negative) and repeating the dose within 72 hours after delivery if the baby is Rh-positive.

questions.text: A 3-year-old boy presents with mental retardation and an inability to walk. The fundoscopy image is given below. What is the most likely diagnosis?(NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Tay-Sachs disease

 

  • The clinical scenario and fundoscopy image suggest the diagnosis of Tay-Sachs disease.
  • Tay-Sachs disease is a lysosomal storage disease caused by the deficiency of hexosaminidase.
  • It presents during infancy with macrocephaly, increased startle reaction, gradual loss of motor skills, and a macular cherry-red spot.
  • Hunter disease is an X-linked disorder that presents with short stature, joint stiffness, and intellectual disability.
  • Hurler syndrome is an autosomal recessive condition that affects multiple organs and presents with corneal clouding, coarse facial features, joint stiffness, skeletal dysplasia, glaucoma, retinal degeneration, and nasal discharge.
  • Gaucher disease is a glycolipid storage disorder that presents with hepatosplenomegaly, mental retardation, and erosion of long bones caused by the deficiency of B-glucosidase.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Hunter Disease: Hunter disease is an X-linked disorder that presents with short stature, joint stiffness, and intellectual disability. It does not typically present with a cherry-red spot on fundoscopy.

 

Option C. Hurler Syndrome: Hurler syndrome is an autosomal recessive condition that affects multiple organs.

 

  • Presentation:
    • Corneal clouding
    • Coarse facial features
    • Joint stiffness
    • Skeletal dysplasia
    • Glaucoma
    • Retinal degeneration
    • Nasal discharge

 

Option D. Gaucher Disease: Gaucher disease is a glycolipid storage disorder caused by the deficiency of β-glucosidase.

 

  • Presentation:
    • Hepatosplenomegaly
    • Mental retardation
    • Erosion of long bones
    • Cherry-red spot may also be seen, but other clinical features and the typical history of Tay-Sachs make it less likely in this scenario.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Tay-Sachs disease presents in infancy with progressive neurological decline, macrocephaly, increased startle reaction, and a characteristic macular cherry-red spot on fundoscopy. It is caused by a deficiency of the enzyme hexosaminidase A.

 

OTHER CAUSES OF CHERRY RED SPOT.

questions.text: Match the diseases with their maximum incubation period. [INICET MAY 2023]
questions.solution:
Ans. (c) 1-d, 2-c, 3-a, 4-b

 

The incubation periods for the diseases listed are as follows:

 

  • Hepatitis A: Maximum incubation period is 50 days.
  • Chickenpox: Maximum incubation period is 21 days.
  • SARS: Maximum incubation period is 10 days.
  • Syphilis: Maximum incubation period is 90 days.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: Which of the following hormones will be secreted in high amounts by the ovarian granulosa cells during the follicular phase of the menstrual cycle? (INICET MAY 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Estrogen

 

During the follicular phase of the menstrual cycle, the granulosa cells of the developing follicles secrete high amounts of estrogen, specifically estradiol. This phase is characterized by the development of a primordial follicle to the Graafian stage, with atresia of neighboring follicles. The following events occur during this phase:

 

  • Estrogen Secretion: Granulosa cells secrete increasing amounts of estrogen, primarily estradiol, which causes proliferation of the endometrium in preparation for potential implantation.
  • Up-regulation of Receptors: LH and FSH receptors are up-regulated in both theca and granulosa cells.
  • Feedback Mechanism: The rising estradiol levels exert a negative feedback effect on the anterior pituitary, suppressing the secretion of FSH and LH to moderate levels.

 

Other Options :

 

Option A. FSH (Follicle Stimulating Hormone): FSH is secreted by the anterior pituitary gland and stimulates the growth of ovarian follicles but is not secreted by granulosa cells.

 

Option C. LH (Luteinizing Hormone): LH is also secreted by the anterior pituitary and plays a role in the later stages of follicle development and ovulation.

 

Option D. Progesterone: Progesterone is primarily secreted by the corpus luteum after ovulation during the luteal phase of the menstrual cycle.

 

Educational Objective:

 

During the follicular phase of the menstrual cycle, ovarian granulosa cells secrete high amounts of estrogen, which is crucial for the proliferation of the endometrium and regulation of FSH and LH levels.

 

Ref: Page no 78, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Gynecology 6th edition

questions.text: At 6 weeks of life, a child developed a fever after DPT vaccination. And now child is 10 weeks due for vaccination. What should be done next? (INICET NOV 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Give DPT Vaccination

 

  • Fever following a DPT vaccination does not necessarily contraindicate subsequent doses. The child should receive the next scheduled DPT vaccination unless there are specific contraindications or severe adverse reactions.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Give DT: Giving only DT (Diphtheria and Tetanus) without the pertussis component may not be ideal for overall protection against these diseases. It's important to provide the complete vaccination schedule, including DPT, unless contraindications exist.

 

Option C. Don’t give DPT: This may not be the best course of action. Fever following the initial DPT vaccination is not an absolute contraindication to subsequent doses. The child should continue the vaccination schedule unless there are specific contraindications.

 

Option D. Don’t give any vaccination: This is not the recommended approach. Missing or delaying vaccinations may leave the child susceptible to vaccine-preventable diseases. It's important to adhere to the recommended vaccination schedule whenever possible.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Understand the approach to managing adverse events following immunization. Recognize that mild reactions, such as fever after a vaccine, do not necessarily contraindicate subsequent doses. Adherence to the recommended vaccination schedule is crucial for providing timely and effective protection against vaccine-preventable diseases

questions.text: A 54-year-old patient who recently recovered from severe COVID-19 infection presents with persistent headaches, anosmia, and confusion. Neurological examination reveals signs of possible central nervous system involvement. Imaging studies and clinical findings point towards viral encephalitis. Based on current knowledge of SARS-CoV-2 neuroinvasion, through which of the following marked sites does the virus most likely spread to the brain?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) A

 

The structures marked in the given image are:

 

A. Cribriform plate

B. Foramen ovale

C. Optic canal

D. Foramen lacerum

 

The cribriform plate, marked as "A" in the image, is recognized as one of the potential entry routes for the SARS-CoV-2 virus to access the brain. The cribriform plate forms the roof of the nasal cavity and has small holes through which the olfactory nerves pass. This structure provides a pathway for the virus to spread from the nasal cavity to the brain via the olfactory nerve endings, potentially leading to neurological complications.

 

Pathway of Infection:

 

The cribriform plate allows SARS-CoV-2 direct access to the brain via the olfactory nerve, serving as a conduit from the nasal cavity.

 

Neurological Implications:

 

The virus can cause neurological symptoms such as encephalitis, demyelination, and neuropathy through entry via the cribriform plate.

 

Clinical Manifestations:

 

Neurological involvement of SARS-CoV-2 can lead to severe complications, including respiratory failure due to viral invasion of the medullary cardiorespiratory centers.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Foramen ovale: Transmits the mandibular nerve (V3) and accessory meningeal artery. It does not provide a direct route for SARS-CoV-2 to spread to the brain.

 

Option C. Optic canal: Carries the optic nerve and ophthalmic artery; it is not involved in the direct spread of respiratory viruses such as SARS-CoV-2 to the brain.

 

Option D. Foramen lacerum: Transmits small vessels and nerves; it does not provide a direct connection between the nasal cavity and the brain.

 

Educational Objective:

 

SARS-CoV-2 can spread to the brain through the cribriform plate, exploiting the direct connection between the nasal cavity and the olfactory system. This route highlights the potential for neurological involvement in COVID-19 and underscores the importance of recognizing neurological symptoms in infected patients for early intervention and management.

questions.text: Identify the grip shown in the image below: (INICET MAY 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Lateral grip

 

Obstetric grips (Leopold manoeuvres)

 

  1. Fundal grip (1st Leopold)
  2. ﻿﻿﻿Lateral/umbilical grip (2nd Leopold)
  3. ﻿﻿﻿1st pelvic grip /Pawlik grip (3rd Leopold)
  4. 2nd pelvic grip (4th Leopold)

 

 

The Lateral grip, also known as the Umbilical grip or Second Leopold's maneuver, is used to assess the position of the fetus in the uterus by palpating the sides of the maternal abdomen. This grip helps determine the location of the fetal back and limbs.

 

Other Options :

 

Option A. Pawlik's grip: Also known as the First pelvic grip or Third Leopold's maneuver, Pawlik's grip involves palpating the lower uterine segment to determine the fetal presenting part (e.g., whether it is a head or breech presentation).

 

Option C. Pelvic grip: This term is sometimes used to refer to the Second pelvic grip or Fourth Leopold's maneuver, which is used to assess the fetal engagement and the degree of descent in the pelvic cavity.

 

Option D. Fundal grip: This is the First Leopold's maneuver, which involves palpating the upper part of the uterus (fundus) to identify the fetal presentation (e.g., head or breech) and the lie of the fetus.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Lateral grip (Second Leopold's maneuver) is used to assess the position of the fetal back and limbs by palpating the sides of the maternal abdomen.

 

Ref: Page 89, DC Ditta’s Textbook of Obstetrics 8th edition.

questions.text: The most common cause of HIV infection in a newborn is: (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Perinatal transmission 

 

The most common cause of HIV infection in a newborn is through perinatal transmission. Perinatal transmission, also known as vertical transmission, occurs during labor and delivery. This can happen when the newborn is exposed to infected blood and cervicovaginal secretions in the birth canal.

 

Mechanisms of HIV Transmission in Infants:

 

  • In utero (During pregnancy): HIV can cross the placenta from the mother to the fetus.
  • During delivery (Perinatal): This is the most common mode of transmission and occurs when the baby is exposed to infected blood and secretions during the birthing process.
  • After birth by breastfeeding: This is a less common mode of transmission compared to perinatal transmission but still significant, especially in regions where breastfeeding is essential for infant nutrition.

 

Risk Factors for Vertical Transmission:

 

  • High maternal viremia (most important)
  • Preterm delivery (<34 weeks)
  • Vitamin A deficiency
  • Prolonged rupture of membranes (>4 hours)
  • Low birth weight
  • Low maternal CD4 count

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Breast milk: While breast milk can transmit HIV, it is less common compared to perinatal transmission during delivery.

 

Option C. Transplacental: HIV can be transmitted transplacentally during pregnancy, but this is not as common as perinatal transmission.

 

Option D. Exchange transfusion with infected blood: This is a rare cause of HIV infection in newborns compared to perinatal transmission.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The most common cause of HIV infection in a newborn is perinatal transmission, occurring during labor and delivery.

questions.text: What is the microscopy technique to produce high contrast image of transparent, live bacteria? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Phase contrast microscopy

 

Phase-contrast microscopy (PCM) is an optical microscopy technique that converts phase shifts in light passing through a transparent specimen to brightness changes in the image. Phase shifts themselves are invisible, but become visible when shown as brightness variations.

 

Contrast is improved by using the difference in thickness or refractive index of structures within and around the cell. Difference in intensity of light is created as rays pass through varied refractive indices and produces contrast thus making the structures within the cells and its surroundings clearly visible.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Dark-field microscopy (also called dark-ground microscopy) describes microscopy methods, in both light and electron microscopy, which exclude the unscattered beam from the image. As a result, the field around the specimen (i.e., where there is no specimen to scatter the beam) is generally dark.

 

Option C. The electron microscope uses a beam of electrons and their wave-like characteristics to magnify an object's image, unlike the optical microscope that uses visible light to magnify images.

 

Option D. Polarized microscopy is used to visualize the intracellular structures using differences in birefringence.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Phase contrast microscopy is the technique used to produce high contrast images of transparent, live bacteria by converting phase shifts into brightness changes.

questions.text: A 5-year-old child presents to the clinic with fever, vesicular lesions on the hands, feet, and oral cavity, along with neck stiffness. The lesions are also present on the palms and soles. A cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) analysis reveals normal glucose levels, elevated lymphocytes, and elevated protein. The child has no significant past medical history, and physical examination shows no signs of systemic bacterial infection. Based on the clinical presentation and CSF findings, what is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Hand-foot-and-mouth disease with viral meningitis

 

The clinical vignette and images suggest Hand-Foot-and-Mouth Disease (HFMD) complicated by viral meningitis. HFMD is commonly caused by enteroviruses such as coxsackievirus A16 and enterovirus 71. The characteristic vesicular lesions on the hands, feet, and oral cavity, combined with neck stiffness and CSF findings (normal glucose, elevated lymphocytes, and elevated protein), point towards viral meningitis, a known complication of HFMD, especially with enterovirus 71.

 

Causes: HFMD is usually caused by coxsackievirus A16 and other enteroviruses like enterovirus 71. In large outbreaks, other coxsackie A and B viruses may also be involved.

 

Clinical Features: Vesicular lesions commonly appear on the tongue, posterior pharynx, buccal mucosa, lips, hands, fingers, buttocks, and groin. The lesions are often more frequent on the hands than on the feet.

 

Complications: Enterovirus 71 can lead to severe complications such as viral meningitis, encephalitis, acute flaccid paralysis, and myocarditis.

 

Diagnosis: Typically diagnosed clinically by the characteristic lesions; viral culture or RT-PCR can confirm the presence of enterovirus. CSF analysis usually shows viral meningitis features: normal glucose, elevated lymphocytes, and elevated protein.

 

Treatment: Primarily supportive care; severe cardiopulmonary disease may require specific agents like milrinone, and immunoglobulins are used in severe cases with variable outcomes.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Herpetic gingivostomatitis: Typically presents with oral lesions but does not involve the palms and soles or lead to viral meningitis.

 

Option C. Varicella (Chickenpox) with meningitis: Characterized by a generalized vesicular rash, not limited to the hands, feet, and mouth.

 

Option D. Kawasaki disease: Presents with fever, rash, and mucocutaneous changes, but does not involve vesicular lesions or viral meningitis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hand-Foot-and-Mouth Disease (HFMD) often presents in children with vesicular lesions on the hands, feet, and oral cavity. When associated with viral meningitis, as seen with enterovirus 71, it highlights the need for accurate diagnosis and management to address potential complications

choices.text: Change the fluid to normal saline
Continue the surgery with careful monitoring of fluid status
Give furosemide to the patient and continue surgery

questions.text: A 25-year-old lady with submucosal fibroid was undergoing myomectomy. The surgeon was using 1.5% glycine as irrigating fluid for the cavity. During the surgery, the nurse informs that there is a 500ml deficit of the irrigating fluid. What is the next step to be done? (INICET NOV 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Continue the surgery with careful monitoring of fluid status

 

During hysteroscopy, systemic absorption of uterine distension fluid occurs through open sinuses or vessels. Increased fluid absorption is seen with higher intrauterine pressure, longer procedure duration, deep myometrial penetration, and a large uterus.

 

Excessive absorption of hypotonic electrolyte-free fluids, such as 1.5% glycine, can cause hypo-osmolality, hyponatremia, cerebral edema, hypotonic encephalopathy, permanent neurologic injury, heart failure, pulmonary edema, and death. However, in this case, the fluid deficit is 500 mL, which is within the allowable limits for a healthy patient.

 

Fluid Management Guidelines:

 

  • Hypotonic solutions (e.g., 1.5% glycine): The maximum allowed fluid deficit is 1000 mL for healthy patients and 750 mL for elderly patients or those with medical comorbidities.
  • Normal saline: The maximum allowed fluid deficit is 2500 mL for healthy patients and 750 mL for those with cardiovascular disease.

 

Fluid absorption can be reduced by:

 

  • Pre-operative treatment with GnRH agonists.
  • Intraoperative injection of dilute vasopressin (0.05 U/mL).
  • Using the lowest intrauterine pressure that provides adequate visualization, ensuring it is below the mean arterial pressure.

 

Management of fluid overload:

 

  • Hypotonic fluid overload: Obtain serum electrolytes and evaluate the patient for volume overload. Asymptomatic hyponatremia can be treated with fluid restriction and careful monitoring of urine output. Symptomatic hyponatremia requires infusion of 3% sodium chloride and management in intensive care.
  • Normal saline overload: Managed by fluid restriction; IV furosemide (20-40 mg) is indicated if there is clinical or radiological evidence of pulmonary edema.

 

Other Options :

 

Option A. Stop the surgery: This is not necessary at a fluid deficit of 500 mL, as it is within the safe limit for a healthy patient.

 

Option B. Change the fluid to normal saline: While normal saline can be used, it is not required to change the fluid type mid-procedure unless there are signs of significant complications or excessive fluid absorption.

 

Option D. Give furosemide to the patient and continue surgery: Furosemide is indicated if there is evidence of fluid overload or pulmonary edema, which is not the case here with a 500 mL deficit.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In the context of a 500 mL fluid deficit during hysteroscopy with 1.5% glycine as the irrigating fluid, it is appropriate to continue the surgery with car

 

Ref: William’s textbook of gynecology 3rd edition pg903

questions.text:
The following are parvovirus-related manifestations. Identify the incorrect pair? (INICET NOV 2022)

 

  1. Pure red cell aplasia - chronic hemolytic anemia
  2. Polymyalgia rheumatica - young women
  3. Hydrops fetalis - pregnant women
  4. Erythema infectiosum - infants
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 2

 

Polymyalgia rheumatica is closely associated with giant cell arteritis in women above 50yrs.

 

Other Options:

 

1. Pure red cell aplasia - chronic hemolytic anemia: Parvovirus B19 can cause pure red cell aplasia, particularly in patients with chronic hemolytic anemia. The virus affects erythroid precursors in the bone marrow, leading to severe anemia in these patients.

 

3. Hydrops fetalis - pregnant women: Parvovirus B19 infection during pregnancy can lead to severe fetal complications, including hydrops fetalis, which is a life-threatening condition characterized by severe edema in the fetus.

 

4. Erythema infectiosum - infants: Erythema infectiosum, also known as fifth disease or slapped-cheek disease, is a common manifestation of parvovirus B19 infection in young children, not just infants. It presents with a characteristic "slapped cheek" rash.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Polymyalgia rheumatica is typically seen in women above 50 years old and is not related to parvovirus infection in young women. Parvovirus B19 is more commonly associated with conditions such as erythema infectiosum in children, pure red cell aplasia in patients with chronic hemolytic anemia, and hydrops fetalis in pregnant women.

 

Additional Information

 

Parvo virus infection -

 

Common symptoms of parvovirus B19 (B19V) infection include a mild nonspecific prodromal illness that may consist of fever (15-30% of patients), malaise, headache, myalgia, nausea, and rhinorrhea; typically beginning 5-7 days after initial infection

 

A diffuse maculopapular rash can appear 1-4 days later and fades to a lacy erythematous rash, which may be pruritic and may spread gradually toward the distal extremities. Most seropositive patients have no history of this classic biphasic illness. The clinical symptoms widely vary, and the classic "slapped cheek" rash is much more common in young children called as erythema infectiosum, also known as fifth disease or slapped-cheek disease,

 

 

Alternatively, parvovirus B19 infection may manifest with purpuric rash, erythema multiforme, or pruritus of the soles of the feet. Parvovirus B19 may cause a papular-purpuric "gloves-and-socks" syndrome (PPGSS), which manifests as an erythematous exanthem of the hands and feet with a distinct margin at the wrist and ankle joints.

 

Transient small joint arthropathy may be the main clinical presentation of parvovirus B19 in adults.

 

Pure red cell aplasia and chronic hemolytic anemia is seen  in patients with immunosuppression.

 

Patients with severe anemia due to transient aplastic crisis (TAC) may present with pallor, fatigue, or signs of an aplastic crisis.

 

Parvovirus B19V infection during pregnancy can lead to hydrops fetalis and/or fetal loss.

questions.text: A 30-year-old female patient, on treatment for infertility, came with 6 weeks of amenorrhea, abdominal pain, and mild vaginal bleeding. Her beta hCG level was 2800 mlU/mL. On ultrasound, a 3cm mass was seen in the left adnexa. It contained a gestational sac with no fetal cardiac activity. What is the most appropriate management for this patient hCG- Human chorionic gonadotropin? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Single dose methotrexate

 

Management of an unruptured ectopic pregnancy can include expectant, medical, or surgical approaches depending on the patient's condition and specific characteristics of the ectopic pregnancy.

 

Medical Management (Single Dose Methotrexate):

 

  • Methotrexate is a folic acid antagonist that inhibits DNA synthesis, effectively treating ectopic pregnancies by stopping the growth of the trophoblastic tissue.
  • Indications for Methotrexate:
    • Patient hemodynamically stable.
    • No significant symptoms.
    • Gestational sac size < 3.5 cm.
    • No visible cardiac activity.
    • Serum βhCG < 5000 IU/L.
    • No contraindication to Methotrexate.

 

In this scenario, the patient has a beta hCG level of 2800 mIU/mL, a 3 cm mass in the left adnexa, and no fetal cardiac activity, making her an appropriate candidate for single-dose methotrexate therapy.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Expectant management:

 

  • Indications:
    • Clinically stable with no pain.
    • Serum βhCG < 1000 IU/L.
    • Tubal ectopic < 35 mm with no visible heartbeat.
    • Ability to return for follow-up.
  • Reason for not choosing: The patient's beta hCG level is 2800 mIU/mL and she presents with symptoms, thus expectant management is not suitable.

 

Option C. Salpingectomy:

 

  • Indications:
    • Significant pain.
    • Adnexal mass of 35 mm or larger.
    • Visible fetal heartbeat on ultrasound.
    • Serum hCG level of 5000 IU/L or more.
  • Reason for not choosing: The patient's ectopic pregnancy size and beta hCG levels do not meet the criteria for surgical intervention. She is hemodynamically stable and a good candidate for medical management.

 

Option D. Milking of the tube:

 

  • Indications: Generally not a recommended procedure due to the risk of incomplete removal of trophoblastic tissue and subsequent complications.
  • Reason for not choosing: This option is outdated and not typically recommended for the management of ectopic pregnancies.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In a stable patient with an unruptured ectopic pregnancy, beta hCG levels < 5000 IU/L, gestational sac size < 3.5 cm, and no fetal cardiac activity, single-dose methotrexate is the most appropriate management option.

 

Ref: Page no 378, William’s Obstetrics 25th edition, https://www.nice.org.uk/guidance/ng126

questions.text: A patient who has taken the first COVID vaccine comes for the second dose. An astute nurse noticed that the shoulder was flabby, flat, and was asymmetrical. There was an associated loss of contour of the shoulder joint. Injury to which of the structures might have resulted and was avoidable?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Axillary nerve

 

The given clinical vignette is suggestive of injury to axillary nerve which leads to deltoid muscle palsy.

 

The deltoid muscle is supplied by the axillary nerve. Iatrogenic damage to the axillary nerve can happen during transaxillary procedures on the shoulder with lateral deltoid-splitting incisions or while administering IM injections inappropriately. But, note that this nerve is commonly injured during shoulder dislocation (most commonly anterior type) or fractures of the humeral neck as both the nerve and the posterior circumflex vessels (pass horizontally and posterior to the neck of the humerus).

 

 

Injury to the axillary nerve can lead to:

 

  • Weakness of abduction and lateral rotation of the arm
  • Retropulsion (extension of the shoulder with the arm abducted to 90 degrees) is impossible.
  • Atrophy of the Deltoid muscle leading to the loss of muscle contours of the shoulder
  • Loss of sensation in the Regimental badge area

 

The described symptoms point towards a condition known as "Shoulder Injury Related to Vaccine Administration" (SIRVA). SIRVA can occur if the vaccine is injected too high in the upper arm, potentially causing inflammation or damage to the structures underlying the deltoid muscle, especially the axillary nerve.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Rotator Cuff: The rotator cuff is a group of four muscles (supraspinatus, infraspinatus, teres minor, and subscapularis) that stabilize and allow various movements of the shoulder joint. Injury to the rotator cuff often results from trauma, repetitive use, or degeneration and leads to pain, especially with overhead activities, and weakness in the arm. A rotator cuff injury would not typically cause the "flabby, flat, asymmetrical" appearance described unless there was a significant tear and muscle atrophy. However, this type of injury wouldn't be directly associated with vaccine administration.

 

Option B. Posterior Circumflex Artery: The posterior circumflex humeral artery is a branch of the axillary artery that runs posteriorly around the surgical neck of the humerus. Injury to this artery might result in bleeding and potentially hematoma formation but wouldn't lead to the described flabby, flat appearance of the shoulder or loss of contour.

 

Option C. Lateral Cutaneous Nerve of Arm: The lateral cutaneous nerve of the arm, also known as the lateral brachial cutaneous nerve, is a sensory nerve that provides sensation to the lateral part of the upper arm. Injury to this nerve would result in sensory loss or tingling in its distribution area but would not cause the observed morphological changes or affect the contour of the shoulder.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The axillary nerve arises from the posterior cord of the brachial plexus and supplies the deltoid muscle and the teres minor muscle. It also carries sensory fibers for the skin over a part of the deltoid (known as the "regimental badge area").

 

Damage to the axillary nerve can result from shoulder dislocations or, as in this case, a vaccine administered too high on the arm. Injury to the axillary nerve would cause paralysis of the deltoid muscle, leading to a flat shoulder appearance and loss of the normal rounded contour of the deltoid. Over time, if the nerve does not recover, the deltoid muscle may atrophy, further accentuating the flat appearance.

questions.text: Which of the following is a component of the neuromuscular criteria for maturity according to the expanded New Ballard score? (AIIMS MAY 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Scarf sign

 

The extended new Ballard score has a component of scarf sign which is a component of the neuromuscular maturity. The New Ballard Score is an extended to include extremely pre-term babies i.e. up to 20 weeks.

 

The scoring relies on the intra-uterine changes that the fetus undergoes during its maturation. Whereas the neurological criteria depend mainly upon muscle tone, the physical ones rely on anatomical changes. The neonate (less than 37 weeks of age) is in a state of physiological hypotonia. This tone increases throughout the fetal growth period, meaning a more premature baby would have lesser muscle tone.

 

Scarf sign: If the infant's arm is pulled medially across the chest (as shown in the image below)

 

 

  • In a hypotonic infant, the elbow will cross the midline.
  • In a term infant with a normal tone, the elbow will not reach the midline.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Heel-knee test: Heel to knee test is not a part of ballard score

 

Option B. Finger-nose test: Finger to nose test is done to assess the cerebellar function.

 

Option D. Cubital angle: The cubital angle, also known as the carrying angle, is measured during the Services Selection Board (SSB) testing process. This has no role in ballard score.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The extended new Ballard score has a component of scarf sign which is a component of the neuromuscular maturity

questions.text: Imagine a scenario where a novel medication is introduced that significantly reduces mortality from a specific disease but does not actually cure the disease.
