As patients continue to live longer with the disease due to this medication, it would have an effect on the epidemiological metrics. Which of the following statements correctly describes the expected change in prevalence and incidence as a result of this medication? [INICET NOV 2021]
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Increase in prevalence

 

  • The given scenario shows that there is a drug which can reduce mortality but cannot cure a particular disease.
  • So, old cases will live longer and thus, there will be increase in prevalence. Incidence will not get affected due to this.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Decrease in incidence: Incorrect, as the medication does not affect the rate at which new cases occur.

 

Option B. Decrease in prevalence: Incorrect, since patients living longer with the disease will increase prevalence.

 

Option C. Increase in incidence: Incorrect, because incidence measures new cases, not the duration or survival of existing cases.

 

Educational Objective:

 

PREVALENCE

 

  • Total current (Old + New) cases in a given population over.
  • Prevalence = Incidence × Mean duration of disease [P = I × d]
  • Prevalence describes the balance between incidence, mortality and recovery

 

INCIDENCE

 

  • Number of new cases occurring in a defined population over a specified period of time.

choices.text: a, b, c, d are correct

questions.text:
Which of the following statements are correct regarding investigation of malignant bone tumors? (AIIMS NOV 2019)

 

  1. Always done by transverse incision.
  2. Sample should be taken from 2 different planes.
  3. Sample should be taken before any radiological investigations.
  4. Sample should be taken from periphery and not from necrotic centre.
questions.solution:
Ans. C) b and d are correct

 

  • Longitudinal incision is given for bone biopsy.
  • Sample should be taken from 2 different planes.
  • Radiological investigations are usually done before the biopsy.
  • It is better to take tissue at the periphery of the lesion, where there are viable cells. On the contrary, necrosis and so nondiagnostic tissue are usually present within the tumor. 

 

SIMPLE BONE CYST

 

  • Simple bone cysts are a common pseudotumor of bone and the most frequent cause of pathologic fractures in children.
  • Bone cysts usually affect patients between 5 and 15 years of age and occur more often in boys than in girls (2:1).
  • They are found in the proximal humerus in 50% of cases and in the upper femur in 25%. The calcaneus and pelvis are also uniquely common locations.
  • Patients are asymptomatic until a pathologic fracture occurs.
  • Radiographs typically show a solitary cyst that is centrally located in the metaphyseal area and has marked thinning of the adjacent cortical bone and a pseudoloculated appearance.
  • If there is associated fracture, radiographs may show the characteristic “fallen leaf” sign.
  • In weight-bearing bones, such as the proximal femur, lesions should be treated aggressively.
  • Management:
    • Initial management usually involves aspiration/injection with either bone marrow or corticosteroid.
    • The injections are carried out with bone biopsy needles and are repeated three to five times at intervals of 2 to 3 months, depending on the radiographic response.
    • Curettage and bone grafting may also be an effective modality.

 

OSTEOID OSTEOMA

 

  • The most common benign osteoid-forming tumor is the osteoid osteoma, accounting for 10% of all benign bone tumors.
  • It is more common in males than in females with a peak incidence in the second decade of life.
  • Although it may be present in almost any bone, the proximal femur is the most common location.
  • Dull, aching, nocturnal pain is characteristic, and  it is commonly relieved entirely by nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs) secondary to a high concentration of prostaglandins in the nidus.
  • Radiographic Feature:
    • Central, lytic nidus usually 1 cm or less in diameter. The more common cortically-based lesion exhibits extensive reactive sclerosis, creating a fusiform bulge on the bone surface. If the nidus is close to, or actually in, a joint, as in a femoral neck lesion, the resulting reactive synovitis may mimic a pyarthrosis or rheumatoid arthritis.
    • Technetium bone scans are invariably positive.
    • A CT scan is recommended to better anatomically locate the nidus and confirm the diagnosis.
    • In the spine, the typical location for an osteoid osteoma is in the posterior elements.
  • Management:
    • Many cases of osteoid osteoma are stage 1 lesions and can be treated symptomatically with aspirin or NSAIDs until they spontaneously resolve.
    • If the patient fails such treatment, intervention is warranted.
    • CT-guided radiofrequency ablation has emerged as the preferred treatment modality in many cases.
    • If open surgical excision is undertaken, the entire nidus must be eradicated.

 

GIANT-CELL TUMOR (OSTEOCLASTOMA)

 

  • It is bone lesion of uncertain origin, most commonly seen in distal femur, proximal tibia, proximal humerus and distal radius.
  • Most commonly seen in 20-40 years of age, after epiphyseal fusion.
  • Histology: 
    • Multinucleated giant cells are seen on a background of stromal cells with little or no visible intercellular tissue.
    • The osteoclast giant cells are the malignant cells, which induce the proliferation of mononuclear macrophage-lineage cells, hence the dividing cell population is the mononuclear cells which form the matrix.
  • Clinical Features:
    • Most commonly presents with pain, with or without swelling
    • Pathological fracture occurs in 10–15% of cases
    • Pulmonary metastasis occurs in 4% of cases, but they usually regress spontaneously.
  • Radiological features:
    • Eccentric lytic lesion at epiphyseal region, bounded by subchondral bone plate, with soap bubble appearance.
    • Biopsy is necessary for confirming the diagnosis.
  • Treatment:
    • Curettage and ‘stripping’ of the cavity, followed by swabbing with hydrogen peroxide or by the application of liquid nitrogen.
    • More aggressive tumors and recurrent lesions: Excision followed by bone grafting.

 

OSTEOSARCOMA

 

  • The classic form of osteosarcoma is typically seen in patients in their second or third decade, with a peak in the adolescent growth spurt.
  • Incidence is Males > Females and is found in the metaphyseal areas of long bones, with 50% of lesions about the knee joint.
  • The distal femur is the most common site, followed by the proximal tibia and then the proximal humerus.
  • Radiographic Findings:
    • Permeated lytic destruction of metaphyseal bone, with eventual cortical breakthrough into the subperiosteal space and subsequent formation of a Codman triangle at the diaphyseal end of the tumor.
    • As the tumor continues to push its way into the extracortical soft tissue, a typical sunburst pattern of neoplastic bone may be seen outside the involved bone.
  • Management:
    • With the combination of chemotherapy and surgical treatment, the prognosis for 5-year survival is 70-80%.
    • The drugs commonly used today include high-dose methotrexate, doxorubicin, cisplatin, and ifosfamide.
    • In osteosarcoma of the extremities, limb-sparing surgery with wide resection of the tumor is the standard approach.
    • Amputation is reserved for the exceptional or recurrent case.

 

Educational Objective :

 

  • Longitudinal incision is given for bone biopsy.
  • Sample should be taken from 2 different planes.
  • Radiological investigations are usually done before the biopsy.
  • It is better to take tissue at the periphery of the lesion, where there are viable cells. On the contrary, necrosis and so nondiagnostic tissue are usually present within the tumor.

questions.text: A psychotic patient developed voluntary purposeless movements and was once observed to be standing still for hours with waxy flexibility and negativism. What is the appropriate medical management?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Lorazepam

 

The patient's presentation suggests catatonia, which can manifest with features like waxy flexibility, negativism, and purposeless movements.

 

Lorazepam is a first-line treatment for catatonia. It often provides rapid relief of symptoms.

 

Other Options :

 

Option A. Haloperidol is an antipsychotic that can be used in psychotic disorders, but it is not the first-line treatment for catatonia. Additionally, antipsychotics might exacerbate or even induce catatonia.

 

Option C. Clonidine and Option D. Propranolol are not used as primary treatments for catatonia.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Catatonia is a neuropsychiatric syndrome that can manifest with features like waxy flexibility, negativism, and purposeless movements. Lorazepam is a first-line treatment for catatonia and can provide rapid symptom relief. ECT is considered to be the treatment of choice.

 

Reference: A Short Textbook of Psychiatry, 7th edition, Page No 59, 67.

choices.text: Produces non-lactose fermenting colonies on MacConkey agar
Exhibits satellitism around Staphylococcus aureus colonies
It exhibits alpha hemolysis on sheep blood agar

questions.text: A child was brought with complaints of high fever, multiple seizures, headache, and neck rigidity. CSF analysis showed low glucose, high protein, and many polymorphs. The CSF culture showed pleomorphic gram-negative bacilli. What is true about the causative organism? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Exhibits satellitism around Staphylococcus aureus colonies

 

The patient with given complaints points to meningitis caused by Haemophilus influenzae and it exhibits satellitism around Staphylococcus colonies. When present in the sputum, H. influenzae appears as a coccobacillus, but in cerebrospinal fluid (CSF), it appears as a filamentous bacillus.

 

H. influenzae can grow on blood agar if the source of V factor is provided

 

When S. aureus is streaked across a blood agar plate perpendicular to the H. influenzae streak line, then factor V is released from S. aureus.

 

It forms larger colonies adjacent to S. aureus streak line and size of the colonies decreases gradually away from the S. aureus streak line, this is known as Satellitism. Therefore, used for the isolation of H. influenzae.

 

 

 

H. influenzae requires growth factors V and X that are present in the blood.

 

  1. Factor X = hemin→ present freely in blood
  2. Factor V = Nicotinamide adenine dinucleotide (NAD) →present inside RBCs (also produced by some bacteria, such as Staphylococcus aureus)

 

H. influenzae can cause meningitis, epiglottitis, pneumonia, bronchitis, and less commonly suppurative lesions like arthritis, endocarditis, and pericarditis.

 

DOC - Cefotaxime or ceftazidime

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. It is bacitracin sensitive: Bacitracin sensitivity is a characteristic of Streptococcus pyogenes, a Gram positive coccus.

 

Option B. Produces non-lactose fermenting colonies on MacConkey agar: Associated with organisms such as Shigella, Salmonella, and Proteus species.

 

Option D. It exhibits alpha hemolysis on sheep blood agar: Alpha-hemolysis on blood agar is a characteristic of Streptococcus pneumonia, a gram-positive coccus.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In cases of suspected Haemophilus influenzae infection, particularly meningitis, look for satellitism around Staphylococcus aureus on blood agar, indicating the organism's dependence on externally sourced V factor for growth.

questions.text: A 13-year-old boy presents with right-sided nasal obstruction and recurrent epistaxis for the past 6 months. What is the most likely diagnosis? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) JNA

 

Juvenile nasopharyngeal angiofibroma (JNA) is a benign but locally aggressive vascular tumor that occurs almost exclusively in adolescent males. The typical presentation includes nasal obstruction and recurrent episodes of epistaxis (nosebleeds).

Other Options:

 

Option B. Allergic Rhinitis: Nasal obstruction but no recurrent epistaxis.

 

Option C. Coagulation Disorder: Bleeding from multiple sites, not specific to nasal obstruction in adolescent males.

 

Option D. Antrochoanal Polyp: Nasal obstruction without recurrent epistaxis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Juvenile nasopharyngeal angiofibroma (JNA) is the most likely diagnosis for a 13-year-old boy with right-sided nasal obstruction and recurrent epistaxis, as it commonly presents in adolescent males with these symptoms.

questions.text: Dr. Sharma was enthusiastically reviewing the results of a randomized controlled trial (RCT) that aimed to compare the therapeutic benefits of Drug A and Drug B. To her surprise, the data suggested a statistically significant difference between the two medications, indicated by a p-value of <0.005. However, after a comprehensive review and collaboration with other experts, it was established that in real-world settings, both drugs had essentially equivalent therapeutic outcomes. This error in interpretation, where a difference was falsely identified when none existed in reality, is best described by which of the following statistical terms? [AIIMS MAY 2017]
questions.solution:
Ans. (a) Alpha error

 

  • In the given scenario, null hypothesis (H0) can be that the two drugs being the same in effectiveness is true in reality.
  • The alternative hypothesis will be that both drugs are different.
  • Since P-value was found to be < 0.005, means that data is statistically significant and thus, null hypothesis is rejected.
  • But it is already established that the null hypothesis is true and now if we accept the alternative hypothesis even though it is false, this will be a type I error or alpha error.
  • Hypothesis (H): Is an assumption about the status of a phenomenon
  • Null Hypothesis (H0): In Biostatistics, when we have to prove a particular hypothesis about difference between 2 regimens, we make Null Hypothesis (For examples, If we have to prove that new treatment is better than older treatment, H0 = new treatment is not better than older treatment).

 

Statistical errors:

 

 

Type I Error (Alpha Error):

 

  • Null hypothesis is true but rejected
  • Probability of Type I error is given by ‘P – value’ (probability of declaring a significant difference when actually it is not present)
  • Significance (a) level: is the maximum tolerable probability of Type I error
  • Alpha is fixed in advance: P – value calculated can be less than, equal to or greater than alpha (a)
  • Keep Type I error to be minimum (P < a): Then results are declared statistically significant

 

Type II Error (Beta Error):

 

  • Null hypothesis is false but not rejected (or accepted)
  • Probability of Type II error is given by beta (b) (probability of declaring no significant difference when actually it is present)

choices.text: Focal area of decreased air entry will be suggestive of foreign body
In complete obstruction, ball and valve mechanism causes hyperinflation
The child has developed acute laryngotracheobronchitis

questions.text: A previously healthy child presented with acute-onset dyspnea. A chest X-ray shows unilateral hyperinflation of the lungs. What is true for this patient? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Focal area of decreased air entry will be suggestive of foreign body

 

The clinical presentation suggests the presence of a foreign body in the airway, most likely in the bronchi, causing incomplete airway obstruction. This would be evident on auscultation as a focal area of decreased air entry. This condition is more common in children under 4 years old, and food items are the most common foreign bodies. Non-irritating types, such as plastic, glass, or metallic foreign bodies, and irritating types, such as vegetables, peanuts, beans, and seeds, are frequently encountered. The right bronchus is more susceptible to foreign body impaction because it is wider and more in line with the tracheal lumen.

 

Evaluation:

 

  • A plain X-ray chest in posteroanterior and lateral views (expiratory films are useful) is performed to evaluate a foreign body in the airway.
  • The X-ray may show the radio-opaque foreign body's size, shape, and location, lobar or segmental atelectasis in complete airway obstruction, or hyperinflation or obstructive emphysema of the affected area due to the ball valve mechanism.

 

Management:

 

  • The management of foreign body airway depends on the location of the foreign body.
  • A laryngeal foreign body can be treated with the Heimlich maneuver, and if it fails, cricothyrotomy or emergency tracheostomy should be performed.
  • Foreign bodies in the trachea and bronchi can be removed using a rigid bronchoscope after adequate hydration and emptying of the stomach.
  • Appropriate antibiotics are given to prevent secondary infection.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Flexible bronchoscopy used for removal: Rigid bronchoscopy is preferred over flexible bronchoscopy for the removal of foreign bodies in the trachea and bronchi because it allows better visualization and manipulation.

 

Option C. In complete obstruction, ball and valve mechanism causes hyperinflation: Incomplete obstruction, not complete obstruction, is associated with the ball valve mechanism, which causes hyperinflation by allowing air to enter but not leave the affected area.

 

Option D. The child has developed acute laryngotracheobronchitis: Laryngotracheobronchitis, or croup, is caused by the parainfluenza virus. It commonly affects children aged 6 months to 3 years and presents with a barking cough, biphasic stridor, and low-grade fever. The chest X-ray shows a narrowing of the subglottic region known as the steeple sign, which is not consistent with the presented case of foreign body aspiration.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In cases of acute-onset dyspnea with unilateral hyperinflation on chest X-ray, a focal area of decreased air entry is suggestive of foreign body aspiration, which is more common in children under 4 years old.

questions.text: Which of the following is the best screening investigation for metabolic disorders?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Tandem mass spectrometry

 

Tandem Mass Spectrometry

  • Two mass spectrometers (MS) are arranged sequentially.
  • The first MS separates big peptides, based on their mass.
  • From this observation, a single peptide can be directed into the second MS (called parent ion or precursor ion). The parent ion enters the collision cell of the second MS. Here the ions collide with argon gas molecules and are broken into smaller ions. These daughter ions (product ions) are detected and quantified by their mass spectrum in the second instrument.
  • The high selectivity of MS-MS is that the parent ion mass and daughter ion mass are used for characterization.
  • The applications of MS-MS include:
    • Identification and quantification of proteins
    • Drug screening
    • Pesticides
    • Pollutants
    • Screening of inborn errors of metabolism, especially organic acidurias.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Western blot:

  • Function: Used for detecting specific proteins in a sample using antibody binding.
  • Limitation: Not suitable for broad metabolic disorder screening; used for protein analysis.

 

Option C. PCR (Polymerase Chain Reaction):

  • Function: Amplifies DNA sequences for genetic analysis.
  • Limitation: Highly specific for known genetic mutations; not suitable for comprehensive metabolic screening.

 

Option D. Gel electrophoresis:

  • Function: Separates molecules (DNA, RNA, proteins) based on size and charge.
  • Limitation: Not specific or sensitive enough for broad metabolic disorder screening.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Tandem mass spectrometry (MS/MS) is the preferred method for screening metabolic disorders due to its ability to simultaneously analyze multiple metabolites with high sensitivity and specificity.

questions.text: Identify the marked ligament?  (INICET NOVEMBER 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) PCL

 

In the image, the arrow points to a structure consistent with the location and orientation of the PCL. The PCL  attaches to the posterior tibial condyle.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. ACL (Anterior Cruciate Ligament): The ACL, crosses in the middle of the knee with the PCL but is positioned anteriorly on the tibia.

 

Option C. Meniscus: They are located throughout the articular surface of knee joint

 

Educational Objective :

 

The marked ligament in the MRI scan is the PCL (Posterior Cruciate Ligament). This identification is supported by the ligament's location and trajectory as depicted in the image.

choices.text: Acute motor axonal neuropathy
Acute inflammatory demyelinating polyneuropathy
Acute motor sensory axonal neuropathy
Miller Fisher syndrome

questions.text: Which of the following is the most common type of Guillain-Barre syndrome? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Acute inflammatory demyelinating polyneuropathy

 

Acute inflammatory demyelinating polyneuropathy (AIDP) is the most common form of Guillain-Barre syndrome (GBS) in the United States and Europe. It presents with rapidly ascending motor weakness and, at times, sensory disturbances in the form of paresthesia. The pathological hallmark of AIDP is the demyelination of peripheral nerves, leading to slow nerve conduction velocities as detected on electromyography.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Acute motor axonal neuropathy (AMAN): While AMAN is more common in certain regions like East Asia, it is less prevalent than AIDP in most parts of the world. AMAN is characterized by the involvement of motor fibers without significant demyelination.

 

Option C. Acute motor sensory axonal neuropathy (AMSAN): Similar to AMAN but involves both motor and sensory fibers. It is generally more severe but less common than AIDP.

 

Option D. Miller Fisher syndrome: A rare variant of GBS that is characterized by ataxia, areflexia, and ophthalmoplegia. It is considered a variant of GBS associated with anti-GQ1b antibodies.

 

Educational Objective:

 

AIDP is the most common type of GBS presenting with ascending motor weakness with occasional distal sensory paresthesia due to demyelination of posterior column.

 

Axonal variants:

 

  • AMAN (Acute motor axonal neuropathy): GM1a, GD1a    
  • AMSAN (Acute motor & sensory axonal neuropathy): GM1a, GD1a         

 

Other variants

 

  • Acute motor conduction block neuropathy: GM1a, GD1a
  • Pharyngo-cervico-branchial variant: GT1a
  • Miller-Fischer variant: GQ1b >> GT1a
  • Acute ataxic neuropathy: GQ1b >> GT1a
  • Pure sensory ataxic variant: GD1b
  • Bickerstaff brainstem encephalitis (BBE): GQ1 >> GT1a

 

Reference - Adam and Viktor/Peripheral neuropathy/GBS page 1322

questions.text: The absence of loud S1 in mitral stenosis would indicate all of the following, except: (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Mild mitral stenosis

 

The first heart sound (S1) is produced by the closure of the mitral and tricuspid valves at the beginning of systole. In mitral stenosis, the loudness of S1 can vary depending on several factors. A loud S1 is typically associated with the early stages of mitral stenosis when the valve leaflets are still relatively mobile. However, in certain conditions, S1 can become softer.

 

In mild mitral stenosis without significant calcification usually results in a loud S1. This is because the mitral valve leaflets are still relatively mobile and can close forcefully. Therefore, mild mitral stenosis is the correct exception in this context, as it does not typically cause a soft S1.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Calcified valve: When the mitral valve becomes calcified, it loses its mobility. This results in a softer S1 because the valve leaflets are not able to close rapidly or forcefully.

 

Option B. Aortic regurgitation: Aortic regurgitation can lead to an increased preload in the left ventricle, which can in turn affect the closure of the mitral valve, making S1 softer. Additionally, mitral regurgitation, which often coexists with mitral stenosis, can also soften S1.

 

Option C. First degree heart block: In first degree AV block, there is a prolonged PR interval. This delayed conduction can lead to a less forceful closure of the mitral valve, resulting in a softer S1.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In mitral stenosis, a loud S1 is typically seen in the early stages with mobile valves, while a soft S1 can indicate valve calcification, aortic regurgitation, or first degree heart block. Mild mitral stenosis without calcification usually results in a loud S1

questions.text: The patient has a fever, cough, and cold. The chest X-ray is given below. What will be the examination finding in the infra-scapular region? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Dull note on percussion

 

The patient's symptoms and the chest X-ray findings indicate pleural effusion. Key features of pleural effusion on a chest X-ray include the meniscus sign and blunting of the costophrenic angle. Clinically, pleural effusion leads to reduced or absent air entry in the affected area.

 

A dull note on percussion is a hallmark sign of pleural effusion. This occurs due to the accumulation of fluid in the pleural space, which does not transmit sound vibrations as efficiently as air-filled lung tissue.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hyperresonance on percussion: This finding is characteristic of pneumothorax, where there is an excess of air in the pleural space, leading to increased resonance.

 

Option B. Coarse crackles: Coarse crackles can be heard in various conditions such as bronchiectasis, the resolving phase of pneumonia, or pulmonary edema. However, they are not typically associated with pleural effusion.

 

Option D. Pleural rub: Pleural rub is a sign of pleuritis or inflammation of the pleura. It is usually absent in pleural effusion due to the separation of pleural surfaces by fluid.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A dull note on percussion is a key clinical finding in pleural effusion, indicating the presence of fluid in the pleural space.

questions.text: A young child with absent thymus is brought to the OPD with features of hypoparathyroidism and tetany. Which of the following marked area in the picture is defective in this condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. 12

 

The patient most certainly has DiGeorge syndrome based on the clinical history and the imaging, which displays pharyngeal pouches (thymic and parathyroid defects). It might be brought on by faulty third- and fourth-pharyngeal-pocket development. The thymus' absence is expressly stated in the provided stem. Hence, choice 12 is the better of the two.

 

  • DiGeorge syndrome is a complex embryopathy that is caused by hemizygous interstitial deletion of chromosome 22, leading to multiple developmental defects, including conotruncal defects, hypoparathyroidism, and dysmorphic syndrome. Microdeletion at chromosome 22q11 can lead to variable presentations including -
  • Cleft palate
  • Abnormal facies
  • Thymic aplasia leading to T-cell deficiency
  • Cardiac defects
  • Hypocalcemia 2° to parathyroid aplasia.

          (Mnemonic: CATCH-22)

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 9 : External Auditory Meatus. The first pharyngeal pouch derivatives include the middle ear cavity, eustachian tube, and external auditory meatus. These structures are primarily involved in auditory functions and do not relate to the endocrine or immune system anomalies seen in DiGeorge syndrome.

 

Option B. 10: Palatine Tonsil. The second pharyngeal pouch develops into the palatine tonsils. While DiGeorge syndrome can include a range of pharyngeal derivatives issues, the palatine tonsil is not typically affected in ways that lead to the major clinical symptoms of thymus and parathyroid gland absence.

 

Option D. 14: Ultimobranchial Body. This derivative of the fourth pharyngeal pouch contributes to the development of the parafollicular cells (C cells) of the thyroid, which are responsible for calcitonin production. Although related to calcium metabolism, its involvement is distinct from the parathyroid gland's role in calcium homeostasis and does not directly relate to the primary symptoms of DiGeorge syndrome.

 

Educational Objective:

 

 

The most relevant site of defect in DiGeorge syndrome, given the symptoms described (absent thymus, hypoparathyroidism, and tetany), is associated with abnormalities in the third pharyngeal pouch—specifically the development of the inferior parathyroid glands and the thymus

questions.text:
Arrange the following in sequential order with regards to the steps of collection of samples for pap smear testing: (INICET NOV 2021)

 

  1. Use posterior vaginal wall retractor
  2. Take the sample
  3. Make smear on a slide
  4. Fix the smear
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 1, 2, 3, 4

 

The correct sequence for the steps of collection of samples for pap smear testing is as follows:

 

Procedure of taking a pap smear:

 

  1. Use posterior vaginal wall retractor: The patient is put in a dorsal position, and Cusco's speculum is introduced to visualize the cervix.
  2. Take the sample: The ectocervix is scraped with Ayre's spatula, and the endocervix is scraped with a cytobrush.
  3. Make smear on a slide: The samples are spread separately on 2 different glass slides.
  4. Fix the smear: The slide is immediately fixed using 95% ethyl alcohol (either immersed or sprayed). After immersion in fixative for 30 minutes, the slide is removed and air dried.

 

Additional Steps:

 

  • Staining: The fixed slide is stained with Papanicolaou stain.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The correct sequence for collecting samples for a pap smear is to first use a posterior vaginal wall retractor to visualize the cervix, take the sample, make the smear on a slide, and then fix the smear using 95% ethyl alcohol.

 

Ref: Dutta’s textbook of gynecology 6th edition Pg 110,111, William’s textbook of gynecology 3rd edition 632, 633

questions.text: A 36-year-old male with a diagnosis of schizophrenia was started on an antipsychotic medication. Within a few weeks, he developed symptoms of Parkinsonism, such as bradykinesia, rigidity, and a shuffling gait. The medical team is considering prescribing an additional medication to manage these extrapyramidal side effects. Which of the following drugs can be given to this patient? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Trihexyphenidyl

 

Trihexyphenidyl is an anticholinergic medication commonly used to treat extrapyramidal symptoms like Parkinsonism that may arise as a side effect of antipsychotic medications. It can counteract the dopamine antagonism caused by antipsychotic drugs, thereby alleviating symptoms such as tremors, rigidity, and bradykinesia.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Entacapone: Entacapone is a COMT inhibitor used in the treatment of Parkinson's disease to prolong the action of levodopa. It's not typically used to treat drug-induced Parkinsonism.

 

Option C. Rasagiline: Rasagiline is a monoamine oxidase type B (MAO-B) inhibitor used primarily in Parkinson's disease. It's not commonly used for drug-induced extrapyramidal symptoms.

 

Option D. Pramipexole: Pramipexole is a dopamine agonist also used in the treatment of Parkinson's disease but is ineffective in treatment of extrapyramidal symptoms induced by antipsychotic medications.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Trihexyphenidyl is the appropriate medication for managing extrapyramidal side effects, such as Parkinsonism, induced by antipsychotic medications. It works by counteracting the dopamine antagonism and restoring the balance between acetylcholine and dopamine in the brain.

questions.text: A 30-year-old patient with heart failure and poorly controlled type 2 diabetes (HbA1c of 7.8%) presents with progressive dyspnea. Which is the preferred antidiabetic drug? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Dapagliflozin

 

Dapagliflozin is a sodium-glucose co-transporter-2 (SGLT2) inhibitor that has shown significant benefits in patients with heart failure, particularly heart failure with reduced ejection fraction (HFrEF). SGLT2 inhibitors, including dapagliflozin and empagliflozin, have been demonstrated to improve survival, reduce heart failure hospitalizations, and delay the progression of heart failure. These benefits make SGLT2 inhibitors the preferred choice for patients with both type 2 diabetes and heart failure.

 

Four Pillars in the Management of HFrEF (Heart Failure with Reduced Ejection Fraction):

 

  1. ARNIs and ACE Inhibitors/ARBs:
    • ARNIs (e.g., Sacubitril/Valsartan) are preferred.
    • ACE Inhibitors/ARBs are also used.
  2. Beta Blockers:
    • Metoprolol
    • Bisoprolol
    • Carvedilol
  3. MRAs (Mineralocorticoid Receptor Antagonists):
    • Spironolactone
    • Eplerenone
  4. SGLT2 Inhibitors:
    • Empagliflozin
    • Dapagliflozin

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Glimepiride: This is a sulfonylurea that primarily helps in lowering blood glucose by stimulating insulin secretion. It does not provide the cardiovascular benefits seen with SGLT2 inhibitors and can increase the risk of hypoglycemia.

 

Option C. Metformin: While metformin is a first-line therapy for type 2 diabetes and has some cardiovascular benefits, it is not specifically indicated for improving heart failure outcomes.

 

Option D. Sitagliptin: This is a dipeptidyl peptidase-4 (DPP-4) inhibitor used to manage blood glucose levels. It does not provide the same level of heart failure benefit as SGLT2 inhibitors.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For patients with type 2 diabetes and heart failure, SGLT2 inhibitors like dapagliflozin are the preferred antidiabetic medications due to their proven benefits in reducing heart failure progression, hospitalizations, and mortality.

questions.text: Sympathetic ophthalmia is a consequence of which of the following?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Penetrating ocular trauma

 

  • Sympathetic ophthalmia is a bilateral granulomatous panuveitis seen after a penetrating ocular trauma.
  • It can occur 2 weeks to 3 months after initial injury in 65% of cases, or following intraocular surgery.
  • The injured eye is called ‘exciting eye’ and the fellow eye is called ‘sympathising eye’.
  • The clinical picture of iridocyclitis in the sympathising eye can be divided into two stages:
  • Prodromal stage: 
    • Earliest symptoms: sensitivity to light (photophobia) and transient indistinctness of near objects.
    • Signs: retrolental flare and cells, a few keratic precipitates (KPs), mild ciliary congestion, slight tenderness of the globe, fine vitreous haze, and occasional disc oedema.
  • Fully-developed stage: 
    • Typical signs and symptoms consistent with acute plastic iridocyclitis.
    • Anterior uveitis develops in both eyes, and multifocal choroidal infiltrates with sub-retinal pigment epithelium (RE) infiltrates corresponding to Dalen-Fuchs nodules can be seen in the mid-periphery of the fundus.
  • Treatment includes:
    • High-dose oral prednisolone for several months.
    • Immunosuppressives such as azathioprine, cyclosporine, and methotrexate for resistant cases or as steroid-sparing agents.
    • Enucleation of a severely injured eye with no visual potential within 2 weeks of injury to prevent the occurrence of sympathetic ophthalmia.

 

Differential diagnosis of Sympathetic Ophthalmia is Vogy-Koyanagi-Harada Disease.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Blunt ocular trauma: typically does not cause sympathetic ophthalmia.

 

Option C. Chemical injury: primarily affects the ocular surface and cornea rather than causing granulomatous uveitis.

 

Option D. Urinary tract infection: is unrelated to ocular conditions and does not cause sympathetic ophthalmia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Sympathetic ophthalmia is a preventable and treatable condition if diagnosed early and managed appropriately. Awareness of its presentation and prompt treatment can prevent severe bilateral vision loss.

questions.text: Which compound among the options is predominantly responsible for the disinfectant quality to bleaching powder? [NEET PG 2020]
questions.solution:
Ans. (c) Hypochlorous acid

 

The primary reason for the disinfectant ability of bleaching powder stems from the activity of hypochlorous acid, which is responsible for its effectiveness. It surpasses hypochlorite ions in effectiveness by a factor of 70-80.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hypochlorite Ion (OCl⁻): While it does have disinfectant properties, it is much less effective compared to hypochlorous acid.

 

Option B. Hydrochloric Acid (HCl): This is a byproduct of the reaction between chlorine and water but does not contribute significantly to the disinfectant quality.

 

Option D. Chloride Ion (Cl⁻): This is also a byproduct of the disinfection process and does not play a direct role in the disinfectant action.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Bleaching powder (CaOCl2)

 

  • 2.5 gms of bleaching powder is sufficient to disinfect 1000L of water.

 

Mechanism of action:

 

  • CHLORINE + IMPURITIES à DESTRUCTION Add some additional Cl2 [free residual Cl2]
  • Main disinfecting action of chlorine in water is due to HYPOCHLOROUS ACID [HOCL] [90% of disinfection] + Hypochlorite ions [10% of disinfection]

 

H2O + Cl → HCI + HOCI HOCI → H + OCI
